newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Lite-On lights up dull market.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Lite-On lights up dull market.

text.p: Taiwan's Lite-On Technology lit up an otherwise lacklustre Asian debt market on Friday with a floating rate note issue.
Lite-on Technology Corp unit LTC HK launched a US$45 million FRN through arrangers Citicorp International and HSBC Markets.

The five-year notes can be put in year three and be called in years three and four. They pay a margin of 70 basis points over the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) and, with fees, an all-in return of 76.6 basis points to top-tier managers.
Earlier this month, Lite-on said it would use the proceeds from the issue to finance the construction of its new plants in Scotland and Mexico and to repay foreign currency loans.
In July, the company said it planned to invest US$78 million in Scotland to make monitors. Lite-on is one of Taiwan's leading computer monitor manufacturers.
Lite-on raised US$71.3 million in September through an issue of global depository receipts.
On Monday, Chase Manhattan Asia will formally launch a US$75 million floating rate certificate of deposit issue for Philippine Commercial International Bank.

The three-year paper pays a coupon of 75 basis points over LIBOR and an all-in return of 85 basis points to top-tier managers. There is a fixed-reoffer price of 99.80 that will hold until the November 11 reply deadline.
In line with the trend for Philippines issues, pricing is tighter than that of PCI Bank's other issues launched this year.

In June, PCI Bank set a three-year FRCD that paid 90 basis points to the top tier. Last month, the bank launched a five-year Eurobond that was priced to yield 120 basis points over comparable U.S. Treasuries.
South Korea's Hanil Bank reportedly is planning to launch a three-year floating rate note issue that will pay 26 basis points all-in to the top tier.
Cho Hung Bank in early October launched a five year non-call three step-up FRN that paid 26 basis points to the call. At the time, dealers said the pricing was tight.

Since then, however, South Korea has been formally asked to join the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, an invitation that bankers said could worth a few, but probably not many, basis points to Korean bank issuers.
On Monday, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will tender its debut 10-year Exchange Fund Note in a bid to lengthen the government debt yield curve.
